newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Palestinians say Israel orders Hebron confiscation.
newsitem.headline: Palestinians say Israel orders Hebron confiscation.

text.p: Palestinians accused Israel on Tuesday, ahead of a pivotal meeting on the future of Hebron, of planning to destroy Arab houses in the West Bank city to build a road for Jews.

Israel said it expected Defence Minister Yitzhak Mordechai to meet Palestinian President Yasser Arafat on Wednesday. Palestinians said they would discuss Israel's long-delayed handover of parts of Hebron to self-rule.

Palestinians said the Israeli army delivered orders written in Arabic and signed by central region commander Major-General Uzi Dayan to Arab landowners in Hebron informing them of an order to confiscate a strip of land between the Kiryat Arba Jewish settlement and al-Ibrahimi mosque in Hebron.
The mosque is inside the traditional tomb of the biblical patriarchs holy to both Arabs and Jews. Hebron is the only West Bank city where both peoples live -- 400 Israelis among 100,000 Palestinians.
Israel occupied the West Bank in the 1967 Middle East war and later the settlers moved in. Israel began handing over parts of the West Bank to self-rule in 1994 under peace deals with Arafat's PLO.

The confiscation order did not mention plans to demolish houses, stating only that the land was being taken for "military purposes". But Palestinians said the Israelis planned to build a road in the area that would cut through the ancient casbah quarter of Hebron, destroying a number of Arab-owned houses.
"My house falls within the area they said they wanted to confiscate," said Nasser Daana, a 30-year-old Palestinian landowner.
"I really see no justification for this road, especially since the Jews already use our city roads," Hebron's Palestinian mayor Mustafa al-Natshe said.
An Israeli army spokeswoman was checking the report.

Hebron is the last of the West Bank Arab cities due to be given self-rule. Under a 1995 peace deal Israel was supposed to hand over parts of the city last March while keeping parts that include the homes of the Jews.

A series of suicide bombings in Israel delayed the handover and the three-month-old right-wing government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been demanding changes in the redeployment map it says are necessary to the settlers' safety.
Palestinians view Israeli redeployment in Hebron as a litmus test for Israel's commitment to the self-rule deals signed by the Israeli government that Netanyahu ousted in May.
